We know that the number of people who got on the bus must be the number of children that were on the bus before minus the number of children that were on the bus after. Let’s call the number of children that were on the bus before “A” and the number of children that were on the bus after “B”. So we know that A – B must be the number of children that got on. We also know that the total number of children that got off must be 68, because there were 68 children that got off. So A – B + 68 must be the number of children that were on the bus before. However, the question tells us that there were 12 children that were on the bus after. So we can rewrite the last equation as A – B + 68 = 12, which gives us B = 12 – 68 = -56, the number of children that got on the bus. We can then solve for A to get A = 12 – (-56) = 68, the number of children that were on the bus before. So the answer is 68 – 12 = 56, the number of children that got off the bus
